articles.description:
Hey devs,
Today I‚Äôm launching something that‚Äôs been close to my heart for a long time:
üëâ Campfires.dev ‚Äì a platform to help developers grow beyond writing code.
Over the years, I‚Äôve spoken to many developers who feel stuck. Ranging from beginners to seniors, I've seen a common pattern. They want to:
Make more impact on their team
Communicate better with stakeholders
Grow their confidence
Or just figure out: what‚Äôs my next step?
I‚Äôve been there myself and I know how overwhelming and lonely that path can feel.
That‚Äôs why I created Campfires.dev: to offer the guidance I wish I had.
Campfires.dev is here to support your career growth with:
üë• Group sessions: Live Q&As, workshops, and peer discussions
1-on-1 Coaching: Personal guidance tailored to your growth goals
If you‚Äôre a developer who wants to:
grow into a senior or lead role
make a real difference in your team
or just gain more clarity and confidence
Campfires.dev was made for you!
‚ÄúI want to grow, but I don‚Äôt know what to focus on.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident with code, but I struggle with soft skills.‚Äù
‚ÄúI feel stuck in a mid-level role.‚Äù
I truly believe career growth shouldn‚Äôt be a solo journey. Let‚Äôs learn, grow, and light the way forward: together.
Check it out here üëâ campfires.dev 
I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts, feedback, or questions!
P.S. If you‚Äôve ever felt ‚Äúnot senior enough‚Äù or ‚Äúnot technical enough‚Äù then you‚Äôre not alone. And you‚Äôre further than you think. üî•
articles.title: üî• Campfires.dev is live! For developers who want to grow beyond code

articles.author: Antonio | CEO at Litlyx.com
articles.description:
Hey folks, I'm Antonio, CEO at Litlyx.
If you're a product person, you know what it means to refactor your code. It's essential for shipping features faster, testing more effectively, and maintaining your codebase over time.
You'll lose at least a month and a half to refactor a decent-sized codebase, but it's worth doing while things are still manageable... before you end up rewriting everything from scratch.
Most startups rewrite everything because it feels easier than refactoring. But if you can afford a couple of months, it's a great opportunity to clear out some technical debt... because unfortunately, debt always needs to be repaid at some point.
What‚Äôs your take on refactoring? Drop it below!
articles.title: We'll change all our codebase because it's time to level up!

articles.author: Edvaldo Freitas
articles.description:
Startups that want to grow with a quality technical product need to understand one key thing: the software development life cycle is much more than just writing code. It‚Äôs about managing the whole journey, from the idea to post-launch support, with technical decisions that directly impact the business.
Even with small teams and tight deadlines, following a basic structure of the development life cycle (SDLC) helps avoid rework, production bugs, communication bottlenecks, and technical debt that can slow the team down over time.
The biggest problems with the SDLC in startups
Startups run in survival mode. That leads to shortcuts. The most common ones are:
Lack of basic processes: deployments without CI/CD, manual QA, no standardization at all.
Rushing without review: code goes straight to m‚Ä¶
articles.title: 7 Stages of the Software Development Life Cycle

articles.author: datatoinfinity
articles.description:
Stemming is the process of reducing a word to its root or base form by removing suffix or prefixes, often using simple rules, without considering the word's context or actual meaning.
For instance, in search engines or library catalogs, users may submit a query with one word (for example, investing) but expect results that use any inflected word form (for example, invest, investment, investments, etc.). By reducing derivational word forms to one stem word, stemming helps information retrieval systems equate morphologically related words.
Inflected words: Words whose forms change based on grammatical context, indicating aspects like tense, number, case or gender. Example run, running,runner. All used in different form of grammar.
Morphology: Morphology is the branch of linguistics that studies the structure of words‚Äîhow they are formed using smaller units called morphemes.
Root morpheme: carries core meaning. Example: run, talk.
Now use nltk for stemming:
write in terminal python and install WordNetLemmatizer and PorterStemmer.

code editor:
PorterStemmer only remove suffix not prefix.
articles.title: Stemming

articles.author: Visual Knowledge Curator
articles.description:
As developers, we deal with complexity daily whether it‚Äôs breaking down a product roadmap, debugging an elusive issue, or learning a new framework.
And in the middle of sprint deadlines and tech debt, clear thinking becomes a competitive edge.
That‚Äôs where mind mapping steps in. It‚Äôs not fluff. It‚Äôs a way to visually debug your brain.
10 Lessons People Learn Too Late


Think of this as your life.lessons.json but visual.
This mind map outlines foundational principles like:
Value your time
Learn to say no
Stay curious beyond code
Relationships > networks
Why it matters:
Ideal Leader


You might be an IC today, but eventually, you‚Äôll mentor, lead, or architect. 
This map distills what leadership actually looks like‚Äîoutside of Jira and Slack.
Topics include:
Emotional intelligence
Leading by example
Decision frameworks
Communication clarity
Why it matters:
How to Improve Public Speaking Skills for Students


Conf talks. Sprint demos. Tech interviews. We all speak, but few do it well.
This map provides a clear approach to structuring talks, dealing with nerves, and speaking with confidence even if you‚Äôre introverted or ESL.
Why it matters:
Negotiation & Conflict Management


Yes, code is logical. People, not so much.
This mind map covers how to handle disagreements whether you‚Äôre negotiating a salary, resolving a merge conflict (the human kind), or discussing project timelines.
Why it matters:
Managing Yourself


Think of this as your developer ops for the brain.
Topics include:
Context switching traps
Timeboxing and flow state
Goal alignment
Reducing burnout risk
Why it matters:
You use diagrams to simplify code. Why not use them to simplify thought?
These mind maps aren‚Äôt just for meetings or retros‚Äîthey‚Äôre tools for cognitive clarity. Start using them to:
Reflect faster
Communicate better
Grow intentionally
articles.title: 5 Mind Maps Every Developer Should Explore to Think More Clearly and Work Smarter

If you've ever juggled workloads across AWS, Azure, and that one aging on-prem server that sounds like a dying microwave, you're in the right place. Grab a coffee (or a stress ball), and let‚Äôs talk about the wild ride that is hybrid and multi-cloud.
Okay, quick refresher (or therapy session, depending on how your last project went):

If you're diving into networking, you‚Äôve probably come across terms like CIDR, subnet masks, and IP ranges. In this post, we‚Äôll break them down and show you how to master subnetting using a free online tool.

üåê What is Subnetting?
Subnetting is the process of dividing a large IP network into smaller, more manageable subnetworks or ‚Äúsubnets.‚Äù It helps with:
    Efficient IP address allocation
    Improved network performance
    Better security and isolation
For example, instead of giving 200 devices access to the full 192.168.1.0/24 network, you can split that into multiple smaller /26 or /28 networks and isolate traffic.
üî¢ What is CIDR?
CIDR stands for Classless Inter-Domain Routing. Introduced to replace the old class-based IP system, CIDR allows you to define IP ranges more flexibly u‚Ä¶

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Tarang Khaitan
articles.description:
Crypto lobby group the DeFi Education Fund and the Uniswap Foundation have said the Securities and Exchange Commission should be hands-off on regulating decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs).
The May 27 letter to SEC Crypto Task Force lead Hester Peirce argued that the agency should not treat DAOs under the purview of the securities-defining Howey test if they‚Äôre ‚Äúsufficiently decentralized,‚Äù as they are not identifiable and are not a coordinated group.
Instead, the pair said DAOs should be treated as individuals or a group of persons unless proved otherwise.¬†
‚ÄúIf a DAO has a dispersed collection of tokenholders who have the opportunity to actively participate in and govern the DAO and the network, it is sufficiently decentralized such that neither the network token for that DAO, nor transactions in which that network token are the object, should be considered a security.‚Äù the letter read.
The letter was issued in response to Peirce‚Äôs Feb. 21 statement, which invited comments on crypto.
Favorable regulatory environment
The SEC has flipped on its crypto enforcement actions under the Trump administration, which successfully installed the former crypto lobbyist Paul Atkins to lead the agency.
Atkins has stated that blockchain technology could usher in new forms of market activity.
Related: Crypto vulnerable if CFTC not given authority, says ex-chair Behnam
The following week, Atkins said that the regulator would not stifle innovation and lambasted the Biden administration‚Äôs approach to crypto.
In a May 20 SEC oversight hearing, Atkins confirmed that the Crypto Task Force‚Äôs first report will be released in the next few months, the group is also holding a series of crypto-related roundtable discussions with industry players.
Magazine: Move to Portugal to become a crypto digital nomad ‚Äî Everybody else is
articles.title: Crypto lobby group says SEC should back off regulating most DAOs

Why are seniors being targeted in crypto scams?            
            
                
Scammers prey on seniors because they view them as financially secure, trusting and less familiar with rapidly evolving technology.
Let‚Äôs understand why seniors are key targets.

Perception of wealth: Many older adults have retirement savings or pensions, making them lucrative targets.
Lower tech fluency: Navigating crypto wallets, private keys and blockchain concepts can be intimidating, something scammers exploit.
Embarrassment prevents reporting: Victims often feel ashamed, making them less likely to report the crime.
Crypto is irreversible: Once funds are sent via Bitcoin or another cryptocurrency, there‚Äôs no reversing the transaction. That‚Äôs a dream scenario for scammers.

According to the Federa‚Ä¶
